title: Notes by the Way; or, what I saw in my rambles
author: Higginson, H. Talbot.
snippet: fortress to defend the ford of the river, which was about the foot of HighStreet, the sand-bank coming up as far as where Skipper Street nowstands, and a river took the place of High Street at this part, which wascrossed by a bridge at Bridge Street. But now the quays extend formore than a mile on each side of the river, to which the largest vesselsafloat can now come up.

title: Around the clock in Europe :
author: Howell, Charles Fish
snippet: shop at the Coventry Lane corner and Richard Lovelace  in dingy quarters up Gunpowder Alley, and is peering wistfully through the arched gateway to the Temple for a glimpse of Lamb's birthplace or Fielding's home or Goldsmith's grave or a sight of those delightful  "old benchers," brusque "Thomas Coventry," methodical "Peter Pierson," and gentle "Samuel Salt." Doubtless he is able even to detect the rich aroma of the chimney-sweeps' sassafras tea in the neighborhood  of "Mr. Read's shop, on the south side of Fleet Street, as thou approachest Bridge Street."

title: The complete poetical and prose works of Robert Burns:
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: Sly direction is— care of Andrew Bruce, merchant. Bridge Street. R. B.

title: Notes by the Way; or, what I saw in my rambles
author: Higginson, H. Talbot.
snippet: From the terrace above what isknown as the Lion's Den, where there are two small chambers built ofstone, in which, it is said, lions were kept, a fine view of the valley ofthe Lagan may be had. The ground is here terraced down to the river,and laid out in gardens, with a deep well at the bottom of some stepsnear Bridge Street, which is supposed to have supplied the castle withwater. Lisburn was once a great place for obtaining recruits for thearmy, particularly the Royal Artillery, which had a captain and recruiting staff quartered in the town; and the men were fine, tall, and wellmade.
